content: hey friends and fellow crafters DM
scotty here great to have you with me have a really special episode where i do
a D&D shadow box so my daughter's are huge fan of D&D
like I am like you know like I am of course and I
want to give her something really special for Christmas so I decided to
make her this D&D shadow box where it looks like her little player characters
are descending into a dungeon and that was kind of the idea of this build now
the build is pretty simple and easy but I do it the video is fairly long because
I do show you me painting the tab loads that go in the dungeon so if that's
something you're interested in watching you know have fun enjoy it you know to
see how I did all the little pictures and tableaus in the box you could skip
through up here if you're not so interested in all that but anyways here
is a look at it I think it came out really fantastic and let me show you how
I made this D&D shadow box here is the six components shadowbox I
was inspired by and I've only seen this at Michael's so it's very has a very low
depth into it but it's perfect for like miniatures you can put miniatures on it
other people don't like it because it's not a very there's not much depth to it
so you can't really put much in the shadowbox but for our purposes it's
great and I didn't want something that stuck out from the wall that much so I
really like this so what I did then is I just spray-painted it flat black the
next thing I did was I wanted to cut foam pieces to fit in each compartment
so I could paint the different like tableaus that would go throughout the
dungeon delft that I was going to have on this piece one tip before you do cut
the cells out for the pieces into the shadow box is there are different sizes
right so some are 4 and 3/4 by 2 and 3/4 and 4 by 2 and 3/4 so make sure you cut
those right the amount right and the size because if you don't you're going
to paint these wonderful pictures on here and then they go they don't fit so
yeah make sure you measure those out first and how many you need before you
actually start cutting the the craft foam out ok
so I've done a lot of prep work here here's the back and it's black now I did
some sponge work here with just a damp sponge in gray acrylic craft paint and
it kind of got on the insides of those so I'm gonna hit the edges of that with
this craft black craft paint so if there's some edges on the tableaus that
show through I won't have any like gray so I just want to fix that so I just did
around the edge I didn't paint the whole thing because I'm just worried about the
edge if the edge of the tableau doesn't exactly fit now I'm going to use my damp
sponge again with a little bit of light gray acrylic craft paint now let's go
around the edges and that gives a really nice highlight you know to that I like
that gives it bringing out those sharp edges right so that's great now we're
ready for the tableaus so for each tableau I'm just gonna draw
a scene I like and this is the entrance of the dungeon you can see that there
just drew it on here with an ink pen there's a gargoyle perched on a you know
pillar there and that kind of thing there's some Kurt you know trees gnarly
trees going up and I just said the most basic of drawing you know I'm gonna fill
this in with paint the reason I use the black foam is I want to kind of a chair
oscuro look where it's like you know the shadows are already filled in I
don't have to worry about filling in the shadows just the highlights so I'm just
gonna use regular acrylic craft paint on here it takes to the foam really well
and this is just basically my modus operandi for the whole thing I'm every
one of these I'm gonna draw a picture on there and then just paint them
you

[Applause]
[Applause]

you
you
[Applause]

you first I Drive fitted and made sure the
pieces were in the right places that I wanted them to be and yeah these are all
great and ready to go next I just had to adhere the tableaus to the piece and I'm
using Eileen's tacky glue because it's really sticky and tacky and it stays in
place so I'm squirts them off on there after I cleared the nozzle and yeah get
that on there now I'm gonna spread it out so I did she's a wide brush and just
pull out to give a nice thin coat on there
sticky gluey coat that I need to adhere this
and then I'll just put it in the first box make sure you got it the right way
and there we go just push down and we're good to go ice nice I got my last one
here my DND inspired one same thing just put the glue on there spread it out with
a wide brush and we're good to go so pop that in
there and we're almost done so cool I really like how that looks so happy with
it nice hope you guys like it I just had
one last thing to do I used this hook on the back and it has these little tack
nails so I used that but before that I squirted some goop on there so I'm got a
nice bond for the back so it won't fall off and might you know break my
miniatures or anything so it's really secure on the back there and ready to
hang so let's hit the wall and see what this looks like with miniatures all set
up on it alright here we go here is the piece hanging on the wall with all my
miniatures on it and super cool I'm really loving it and you can see it
doesn't hold a huge amount of miniatures but you know you got your favorite pcs
up there you know and just I think it just looks so great you know having that
background to put your favorite miniatures up on so there you go guys I
hope you really enjoyed this build I'll see you next time on the craft
